revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:''South Park and Philosophy: You Know, I Learned Something Today''}} {{Infobox book | name = South Park and Philosophy: You Know, I Learned Something Today | title_orig = | translator = | image = South Park and Philosophy Robert Arp.jpg | caption = Book cover | author = [[Robert Arp]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = The Blackwell Philosophy & Pop Culture Series: South Park and Philosophy | subject = [[Philosophy]], [[Popular culture]] | genre = [[non-fiction]] | publisher = Blackwell Publishing | pub_date = December 1, 2006 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = 256 | isbn = 1-4051-6160-4 | oclc = }} '''''South Park and Philosophy: You Know, I Learned Something Today''''' is the first [[non-fiction]] book in [[Blackwell Publishing]] Company’s Philosophy & Pop Culture series and is edited by philosopher and ontologist, [[Robert Arp]], at the time assistant professor of [[philosophy]] at [[Southwest Minnesota State University]].<ref>[http://www.blackwellpublishing.com/book.asp?ref=9781405161602&site=1 South Park and Philosophy: You Know, I Learned Something Today] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070901034507/http://www.blackwellpublishing.com/book.asp?ref=9781405161602&site=1 |date=2007-09-01 }}, Blackwell Publishing, ''Series: The Blackwell Philosophy and Pop Culture Series'', Retrieved 2008-01-21.</ref> The series itself is edited by [[William Irwin (philosopher)|William Irwin]], who is a professor of philosophy at [[King's College, Pennsylvania]] in [[Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania]]. The book utilizes the five classic branches of [[Western philosophy]], namely, [[metaphysics]], [[epistemology]], [[ethics]], [[political philosophy]], and [[logic]], in order to analyze episodes of ''[[South Park]]'' as well as place the show in a context of current [[popular culture]].
The book was published December 1, 2006. The following year, ''[[South Park and Philosophy: Bigger, Longer, and More Penetrating]]''—volume 26 of [[Open Court Publishing Company]]'s Popular Culture and Philosophy series—was published, with editing by philosopher [[Richard Hanley]].<ref>[http://www.opencourtbooks.com/books_n/south_park.htm South Park and Philosophy: Bigger, Longer, and More Penetrating], [[Open Court Publishing Company]], ''Volume 26 in the Popular Culture and Philosophy series'', Retrieved 2008-01-21.</ref>
== Synopsis == The book includes contributions from twenty-two academics in the field of philosophy. Topics include issues of sexuality involved in depicting [[Saddam Hussein]] and [[Satan]] as gay lovers, [[existentialism]] as applied to the death of [[Kenny (South Park)|Kenny]], and a debate about whether [[feminist]]s can enjoy the show due to some of its [[misogynistic]] characters.<ref>"South Park and Philosophy". ''Internet Bookwatch''. April 2007., Copyright 2007: Midwest Book Review.</ref> The contributors to the work utilize philosophical concepts derived from [[Plato]], [[Aristotle]], [[Freud]] and [[Sartre]] and place them in a ''South Park'' context.<ref name="publishers">"South Park and Philosophy: You Know, I Learned Something Today", Book Review., ''Publishers Weekly'', 2006., Reed Business Information.</ref>
The book's contributors all attempted to analyze the philosophical and cultural aspects of ''South Park'' in the work. One of the authors, [[David Koepsell]], wrote about the controversial episode dealing with [[Scientology]], entitled: "[[Trapped in the Closet (South Park)|Trapped in the Closet]]".<ref name="arp">{{cite book |editor-last=Arp |editor-first=Robert |editor2=William Irwin | title = South Park and Philosophy: You Know, I Learned Something Today | publisher = Blackwell Publishing (The Blackwell Philosophy & Pop Culture Series) | date = December 1, 2006 | pages = 27, 59, 60, 118, 120, 132, 137, 138, 140, 224 | id = , | isbn = 1-4051-6160-4 }}</ref> Koepsell cited the fact that the series won a [[Peabody Award]] due to its willingness to criticize intolerance in April 2006 as a "special concern for criticizing and countering intolerance", and the notion that "the Church of Scientology suffers from the widely held perceptions that it seeks to silence former members and others who criticize its beliefs and practices" as the motivation behind the episode.<ref name="arp" /> Koepsell analyzed [[Comedy Central]]'s reaction to the episode itself, in a section of his book entitled "2005–2006: Comedy Central Caves".<ref name="arp" /> He mentions ''South Park's'' usage of the onscreen caption "this is what Scientologists actually believe". in the episode, noting that the same device was used in the episode "[[All About the Mormons?]]". In referencing this similar use of the onscreen caption device, Koepsell seemed to point to an inconsistency in the behavior of Comedy Central relative to the episode. He explained "By a long shot, this show was more kind to Scientology than was "All About the Mormons" to Mormonism."<ref name="arp" /> He noted Comedy Central had suggested it would not rebroadcast the episode for the second time, though it later announced on July 12, 2006 that it would.<ref name="arp" />
== Reception == A review in ''[[The Boston Herald]]'' called the work an "indispensable collection of thought-provoking essays".<ref>"South Park and Philosophy", Book Review, ''[[The Boston Herald]]'', January 5, 2007.</ref> The book was featured on ''The Book Show'' radio program on the [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]. Host Lynne Mitchell wrote that most of the contributors to the book succeeded in teaching philosophy to the reader while discussing the various ''South Park'' episodes. However Mitchell also commented that she was annoyed by a pretend interview by the editor with the creators of ''South Park'', which she felt was made up in "a kind of South Park pastiche".<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/rn/bookshow/stories/2007/2005850.htm Learning from South Park], Lynne Mitchell, ''The Book Show'', [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]], August 14, 2007.</ref> A review in ''Publishers Weekly'' stated that "some of the writers' attempts at lowbrow humor can be embarrassingly off-mark", but also noted that pop-philosophy devotees and South Park fans with a philosophical bent will enjoy the book.<ref name="publishers" />
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071028173155/http://www.blackwellpublishing.com/book.asp?ref=9781405161602 South Park and Philosophy: You Know, I Learned Something Today], Official page at publisher's web site
{{South Park}}

{{EngvarB|date=November 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Use Australian English|date=January 2018}} {{for|a general context to this article|White Australia policy}} {{Refimprove|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox ethnic group |flag = [[File:Australian South Sea Islanders flag.svg|200px]] |flag_caption = Flag of the South Sea Islanders |image = [[File:Nla pic-an24494586 south sea islanders.jpg|300px]]
South Sea Islander labourers on a Queensland [[pineapple]] plantation, 1890s |group = South Sea Islanders in Australia |population = |regions = Sydney{{·}} [[Brisbane]]{{·}} [[Gold Coast, Queensland|Gold Coast]]{{·}} [[Melbourne]] |languages = [[Australian English]]{{·}} |related = [[Melanesians]] }} In an Australian context, '''South Sea Islanders''' refers to Australian descendants of [[Pacific Islander]]s from more than 80 islands in the [[South Seas]]{{spaced ndash}}including the [[Melanesia]]n archipelagoes of the [[Solomon Islands]], [[New Caledonia]] and [[Vanuatu]]{{spaced ndash}}who were kidnapped or recruited between the mid to late 19th century as labourers in the [[sugarcane]] fields of [[Queensland]]. Some were kidnapped or tricked (or "[[Blackbirding|blackbirded]]") into long-term [[Indentured servant|indentured]] service. At its height, the recruiting accounted for over half the adult male population of some islands. There were 60,000 people who were kidnapped or “blackbirded” These people were generally referred to as [[Kanakas]], which means "man", although many Islander descendants now regard the term as [[pejorative]] and an insulting reminder of their ancestors' exploitation at the hands of white planters. With time, owing to intermarriage, many Australian South Sea Islanders also claim a mixed ancestry, including [[Australian Aborigines|Aboriginals]], [[Torres Strait Islanders]] and immigrants from the South [[Pacific Islands]]. Of some 55,000 to 62,500 Islanders recruited, around 10,000 remained in Australia in 1901.Tracey Flanagan, Meredith Wilkie, and Susanna Iuliano. [http://www.hreoc.gov.au/racial_discrimination/forum/Erace/south_sea.html Australian South Sea Islanders: A century of race discrimination under Australian law], Australian Human Rights Commission. The majority were repatriated by the Australian Government in the period between 1906 and 1908 under the '' [[Pacific Island Labourers Act 1901]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.foundingdocs.gov.au/item.asp?sdID=86|title=Documenting Democracy: Pacific Island Labourers Act 1901 (Cth)|publisher=Foundingdocs.gov.au|location=National Archives of Australia|accessdate=14 October 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091026225820/http://www.foundingdocs.gov.au/item.asp?sdID=86|archivedate=26 October 2009|df=dmy-all}} a piece of legislation related to the [[White Australia policy]].Stefanie Affeldt: ''Consuming Whiteness. Australian Racism and the ‘White Sugar’ Campaign''. Lit-Verlag, Münster 2014, pp. 152–188. There was resistance to repatriation,{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article14531561 |title=KANAKA DEPORTATION. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=23 June 1903 |accessdate=15 November 2015 |page=5 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} and controversy regarding the manner in which it was done.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article19489098 |title=KANAKA DEPORTATION. |newspaper=[[The Brisbane Courier]] |date=18 December 1906 |accessdate=15 November 2015 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} Those exempted from repatriation, along with a number of others who escaped deportation, remained in Australia to form the basis of what is today Australia's largest non-indigenous black ethnic group. Today, the descendants of those who remained are officially referred to as South Sea Islanders. A 1992 census of South Sea Islanders reported around 10,000 descendants living in Queensland. Fewer than 3,500 were reported in the 2001 Australian census.Tracey Flanagan, Meredith Wilkie, and Susanna Iuliano. [http://www.hreoc.gov.au/racial_discrimination/forum/Erace/south_sea.html "Australian South Sea Islanders: A Century of Race Discrimination under Australian Law"], Australian Human Rights Commission. The question of how many Islanders were "blackbirded" is unknown and remains controversial. The extent to which Islanders were recruited legally, persuaded, deceived, coerced or forced to leave their homes and travel to Queensland is difficult to evaluate and also controversial. Official documents and accounts from the period often conflict with the oral tradition passed down to the descendants of workers. Stories of blatantly violent kidnapping tend to relate to the first ten or so years of the trade. == Prominent Australian South Sea Islanders == In recent generations, facing many similar forms of discrimination in Australia as Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, Australian South Sea Islanders have been prominent figures in civil rights and politics. [[Faith Bandler]], [[Evelyn Scott (activist)|Evelyn Scott]] and [[Bonita Mabo]] (widow of [[Eddie Mabo]]) are prominent Indigenous activists who are also descendants of South Sea Island plantation workers. [[Stephen Andrew (politician)|Stephen Andrew]], who represents One Nation in the [[Queensland Parliament]], was the first South Sea Islander to be elected to parliament. Another area Australian South Sea Islanders have excelled in is sport, especially the game of [[rugby league]]. Australian international representatives [[Mal Meninga]], [[Sam Backo]], and [[Gorden Tallis]] are all members of the Australian South Sea Islander community. ==Gallery== File:StateLibQld 1 46375 South Sea Islander woman at Farnborough, Queensland, ca. 1895.jpg|South Sea Islander woman at [[Capricorn Coast|Farnborough]], Queensland, ca. 1895 File:StateLibQld 1 127579 South Sea Islander children at Innisfail, Queensland, ca. 1902-1905.jpg|South Sea Islander children at [[Innisfail, Queensland]], ca. 1902–1905 File:PSM V39 D817 South sea islands liku.jpg|South sea islands liku File:StateLibQld 2 86344 Robert Long.jpg|Robert Long. Leader of the South Sea Island Mission at Nambour. File:StateLibQld 2 91336 South Sea Islanders waiting for deportation, Cairns, 1906.jpg|South Sea Islanders waiting for deportation, Cairns, 1906. Departure of the first shipment of deported Polynesians from Cairns under the Commonwealth == See also == *[[White Australia Policy]] *[[Kanaka (Pacific Island worker)]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|South Sea Islanders}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060813174211/http://www.premiers.qld.gov.au/About_the_department/publications/multicultural/Australian_South_Sea_Islander_Training_Package/history/identity/ Background and history of the South Sea Islanders] at the Queensland Department of Premier and Cabinet website. {{Countries and territories of Oceania}} [[Category:Australian people of Melanesian descent]] [[Category:Immigration to Australia]] [[Category:Oceanian Australian]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Australia]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Oceania]] [[Category:Labour history of Australia]] [[Category:Labor history]] [[Category:Slavery]] [[Category:Slavery in Oceania]]

{{Multiple issues| {{confusing|date=October 2010}} {{Update|date=December 2008}} }} [[File:Kirchner and Chavez.jpg|thumb|upright|Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez and Argentinian President [[Néstor Kirchner]], here in 2005.]] The '''maletinazo''', '''valijagate''', or "suitcase scandal" was a 2007 scandal involving [[Venezuela]] and [[Argentina]], souring friendship between the countries.<ref name = "BBCProbes">{{cite news | author = Schweimler, Daniel | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/6946348.stm | title = Argentina probes cash-filled case | work = BBC News | date = 14 August 2007 | accessdate = 14 August 2007}}</ref>
The scandal began when [[:es:Guido Antonini Wilson|Guido Alejandro Antonini Wilson]], a Venezuelan-US entrepreneur, arrived in Argentina on a private flight, hired by Argentine and Venezuelan state officials, carrying US$800,000 in cash which he failed to declare.
Venezuela had enacted strict foreign currency controls in 2003. [[CADIVI]], the commission established by the Venezuelan government to regulate currency, prohibits taking more than US$10,000 in cash out of the country without declaring the money.<ref name="MercoPressStashed"/> Individual Venezuelans could only take US$500 or €400 cash out of the country in a single trip and there was a yearly quota of US$2,500 on credit card expenditures; a special government permit is needed to take additional US dollars out of the country.
The scandal escalated with suggestions that: Wilson was part of Venezuelan President [[Hugo Chávez]]'s personal entourage; the money was meant to help finance, and thus influence, the Argentine presidential candidate [[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner]]; the money was meant to bribe Argentine officials in energy deals for Venezuelan natural gas; or, the suitcase was intended for money-laundering.<ref name="NYTCash-stuffed">{{cite news | author = Barrionuevo, Alexei | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/14/world/americas/14argentina.html?em&ex=1187236800&en=a3d420c29462728f&ei=5087%0A | title = Cash-Stuffed Suitcase Splits Venezuela and Argentina | work = The New York Times | date = 14 August 2007 | accessdate = 14 August 2007 | quote = The scandal has cast a sudden chill over the warmer ties between the countries ... María Luz Rivas Diez, the Argentine attorney general, said Mr. Antonini Wilson had made 12 trips to Argentina in the past year, some for less than a day. She told a Buenos Aires radio station over the weekend that she could not rule out money-laundering as a possible motivation, nor filing charges against Mr. Antonini Wilson, who had been allowed to leave Argentina and whose whereabouts were unknown. Though Mr. Antonini Wilson had been traveling with employees of Venezuela's national oil company, the Venezuelan government insisted that the cash found on him was a personal matter. "The responsibilities are personal,: said [[Pedro Carreño]], Venezuela's justice minister, in comments broadcast Monday on Venezuelan radio. "If there exists a personal object, it is a suitcase."}}</ref> No allegations were proven and the case was closed in 2015 due to the [[statute of limitations]].
The scandal gained further notoriety when [[María del Luján Telpuk]], the Argentine airport police officer who discovered the unreported currency, posed naked a few months later in the Argentine and Venezuelan versions of ''[[Playboy]]'' magazine.
The word Maletinazo comes from ''maletín'' (the Spanish word for suitcase or briefcase) and the suffix [[Spanish nouns#Other suffixes|''-azo'']] which implies intensity or magnitude. The scandal is also known as ''valijagate'', ''maletagate'' and ''maletíngate'' (following the [[List of scandals with "-gate" suffix|-gate]] construction and the Spanish word ''maleta'' or ''valija'' for suitcase or briefcase).{{CN|date=May 2017}}
==Chronicle== [[Image:Cristina F. de Kirchner y Hugo Chávez.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner]] with [[Hugo Chávez]].]] [[List of Presidents of Venezuela|President]] [[Hugo Chávez]] was planning to visit Argentina in August 2007 to refinance billions of United States dollars in Argentine debt through bond purchases and announce a natural gas deal.<ref name="NYTCash-stuffed"/>
On 4 August 2007, Guido Alejandro Antonini Wilson, a Venezuelan-US entrepreneur claiming to be part of Chávez's entourage, arrived in Argentina on a private plane chartered from [[Royal Class]] by Argentine and Venezuelan state officials,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.eluniversal.com/2007/08/15/en_pol_art_public-prosecutor-ap_15A915767.shtml |title=Public prosecutor applies for international arrest of Antonini Wilson |work=[[El Universal (Caracas)]] |date=15 August 2007 |accessdate=17 August 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080108162002/http://english.eluniversal.com/2007/08/15/en_pol_art_public-prosecutor-ap_15A915767.shtml |archivedate=8 January 2008 |df= }}</ref> carrying US$790,550 in cash.<ref name="MercoPressStashed">{{cite news | url = http://www.mercopress.com/vernoticia.do?id=11088&formato=html | title = Another stashed money scandal rocks Kirchner's administration | date = 10 August 2007 | work = MercoPress Independent News Agency | accessdate = 14 August 2007}}</ref> He did not declare the money upon arrival and the police seized the money.<ref name="SuitcaseGirl">{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB119984618762676979 |title='Suitcase Girl' Finds 800 Grand; Stardom Beckons|accessdate=30 July 2008|date=9 January 2008|work=[[Wall Street Journal]]|author=Moffett, Matt |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080511130434/http://online.wsj.com/public/article_print/SB119984618762676979.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 11 May 2008}}</ref><ref name="VenezuelanValise"/> Other Venezuelan passengers on the plane included [[Ruth Behrens]], [[Petróleos de Venezuela S.A.]] (PDVSA) representative in Uruguay; Nelly Cardozo, legal assessor of that company; Wilfredo Ávila, a protocol official; and Daniel Uzcategui Specht, son of PDVSA vice-president Diego Uzcateguil, and Maria Isabel Specht, Technology and Engineering Manager of [[Citgo Petroleum Corporation]] in [[Houston]], Texas.<ref name="UniversalOfficialsTraveled">{{cite news | url = http://buscador.eluniversal.com/2007/08/09/en_eco_art_pdvsa-officials-trav_09A913053.shtml | title = Pdvsa officials traveled with the owner of the USD 800,000 | work = [[El Universal (Caracas)]] | date = 9 August 2007 | accessdate = 14 August 2007}}</ref> Others on that flight were Exequiel Espinosa, president of [[Enarsa]], [[Claudio Uberti]] of OCCOVI (Argentina's Highway Commission), and Victoria Bereziuk, Uberti's secretary.<ref>{{cite web|author=Nelson, Rainbow |url=http://lloydslist.com/ll/news/viewArticle.htm?articleId=1187015898991 |title=Chavez red faced after cash found on plane |publisher=Lloyd's List |date=14 August 2007 |accessdate=14 August 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927163845/http://lloydslist.com/ll/news/viewArticle.htm?articleId=1187015898991 |archivedate=27 September 2007 |df= }}</ref> Although officials originally called it a simple infraction and released Antonini Wilson, both Argentine and Venezuelan officials called for an investigation.<ref name="Fiona"/>
Chávez arrived in Argentina on 6 August 2007, as part of a tour to sign oil deals with several South American countries. Antonini Wilson was in<!--did he actually participate, or was he merely present?--> the signing ceremony between the presidents of Argentina and Venezuela that took place in the presidential palace, also known as the ''[[Casa Rosada]]''.<ref>[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/EdicionImpresa/politica/nota.asp?nota_id=978323&pid=3805133&toi=5828 "Antonini Estuvo en la Casa de Gobierno"] ''La Nación'', 12 January 2008</ref> On 8 August, the Argentine senate demanded a report on the incident. An Argentine judge later ordered the arrest of Antonini Wilson and he faced charges for money laundering and contraband.<ref name="Fiona">Ortiz, Fiona. [https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSN0943585020070809 "Suitcase of cash sparks new scandal in Argentina".] Reuters, 9 August 2007. Retrieved on 22 August 2007.</ref>
==Investigation== Initially, Argentine judge Marta Novatti took the case but she quickly resigned from the investigation. The Argentine government fired one of the state officials who was on the plane, the head of Road Deal Controls, Claudio Uberti. Argentine Minister of Planning, Julio de Vido, declared that Uberti was the "political responsible for that flight";<ref name="ValenteSuitcase">{{cite news|url=http://ipsnews.net/wap/news.asp?idnews=38849 |title=Argentine: Suitcase Stuffed with Cash Triggers Scandal |author=Valente, Marcela |date=9 August 2007 |work=InterPress Service News Agency (IPS) |accessdate=14 August 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929105119/http://ipsnews.net/wap/news.asp?idnews=38849 |archivedate=29 September 2007 |df= }}</ref> Uberti was fired.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://buscador.eluniversal.com/2007/08/09/en_pol_art_argentinean-official_09A913073.shtml | title = Argentinean official involved in portfolio case fired | work = [[El Universal (Caracas)]] | date = 9 August 2007 | accessdate = 14 August 2007}}</ref>
The Argentine minister of interior, Fernández, declared the Senate's attempts to ask for a report on an individual, even if it is a crime case. He said the demand was politically motivated (referring to upcoming elections in Argentina).
PDVSA announced an internal investigation to determine why four of their officials were traveling with Antonini Wilson.
On 13 August 2007, Federal judge [[Diego Zysman]] stepped aside from the case, becoming the second judge to renounce investigating the case.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.eluniversal.com/2007/08/14/en_pol_art_argentinean-public-p_14A915289.shtml |title=Argentinean public prosecutor asks for detention of Antonini Wilson |work=[[El Universal (Caracas)]] |date=14 August 2007 |accessdate=14 August 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080108161953/http://english.eluniversal.com/2007/08/14/en_pol_art_argentinean-public-p_14A915289.shtml |archivedate=8 January 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref name = "ClarinElcaso">{{cite news | url = http://www.clarin.com/diario/2007/08/13/um/m-01477364.htm | title = El caso de la valija quedó sin juez nuevamente y el expediente pasa a la fiscal | work = clarin.com | date = 13 August 2007 | accessdate = 14 August 2007|language=es}}</ref> Judge Novatti was notified by the Judicial Chamber of Economic Cases on 14 August 2007, that she had to take back the case.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.clarin.com/diario/2007/08/15/um/m-01478616.htm | title = Le devuelven a la jueza Novatti la causa de la valija con 800 mil dólares | work = [[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)]]| date = 15 August 2007 | accessdate = 15 August 2007|language=es}}</ref>
The Bolivian government declared the plane carrying [[:es:Guido Antonini Wilson|Antonini Wilson]] to Buenos Aires only flew over Bolivia and did not land there, after some suggestions by Venezuelan officials that the money might have come from Bolivia (it would have been illegal to take that amount of money from Venezuela under current currency control laws.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.eluniversal.com/2007/08/15/en_pol_art_chartered-plane-just_15A915997.shtml |title=Chartered plane just flew over Bolivia |work=[[El Universal (Caracas)]] |date=15 August 2007 |accessdate=15 August 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080108132747/http://english.eluniversal.com/2007/08/15/en_pol_art_chartered-plane-just_15A915997.shtml |archivedate=8 January 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.eluniversal.com/2007/08/15/pol_ava_gobierno-boliviano-d_15A915899.shtml | title = Gobierno Boliviano dice que avión que llevó maletín a Argentina solo sobrevoló su territorio | work = [[El Universal (Caracas)]] | date = 15 August 2007 | accessdate = 15 August 2007|language=es}}</ref>
According to documents from the Supreme Court of Justice of Venezuela from 8 December 2004, an associate of Antonini, sold police equipment through a Venezuelan company [https://web.archive.org/web/20071023174847/http://www.ruibalduran.com/ Ruibal & Duran] to the governor of [[Cojedes (state)|Cojedes state]], Johny Yánez, who days before declared that he did not have anything to do with Antonini. ''Clarín'' newspaper said Antonini had accompanied Yánez on a visit to Uruguay in September 2006.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.clarin.com/diario/2007/08/18/elpais/p-02202.htm | title = Las ametralladoras del socio de Antonini | work = [[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)]]| date = 18 August 2007 | accessdate = 18 August 2007|language=es}}</ref>
Argentina sent an arrest warrant to Interpol for the arrest of Antonini; Interpol released a capture order for the offense of fraud.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.interpol.int/public/data/wanted/notices/data/2007/81/2007_39581.asp |title=Wanted: Antonini Wilson, Guido Alejandro |publisher=[[Interpol]] |date=22 August 2007 |accessdate=22 August 2007 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The investigation in Argentina generated doubt regarding the behavior of members of the Kirchner administration. The investigation is also trying to determine why [[Enarsa]] spent $90,000 for a charter flight, and why Antonini Wilson was allowed to leave Argentina outbound to Uruguay.<ref name="SEMANA">{{cite web | url = http://www.semana.com/wf_InfoArticulo.aspx?IdArt=105633 | title = Valija misteriosa |work= [[Revista Semana]] |date = 18 August 2007| accessdate = 22 August 2007|language=es}}</ref><ref name="CAMBIO">{{cite web|url=http://www.cambio.com.co/mundocambio/738/ARTICULO-WEB-NOTA_INTERIOR_CAMBIO-3684926.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926225042/http://www.cambio.com.co/mundocambio/738/ARTICULO-WEB-NOTA_INTERIOR_CAMBIO-3684926.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=26 September 2007 |title=Por unos dólares de más... |work=[[Revista Cambio]] |date=22 August 2007 |accessdate=22 August 2007 |language=es }}</ref>
== Economic background == {{See also|Economy of Venezuela|CADIVI}}
Venezuela has had strict foreign currency controls since 2003. [[CADIVI]] is the commission established by the government to regulate currency; it prohibits taking more than US$10,000 in cash out of the country without declaring the money.<ref name="MercoPressStashed"/> Venezuelans can only take US$500 or €400 cash out of the country in a single trip and there is a yearly quota of US$2,500 on credit card expenditures; a special government permit is needed to take additional US dollars out of the country.
== Antonini Wilson background == According to ''[[El Nuevo Herald]]'' and ''[[El Universal (Caracas)|El Universal]]'', Antonini Wilson owns a condo in Ocean Club, Key Biscayne, Florida; together with Wladimir Abad, he is registered as owner of a building located in Mashta Avenue, in Key Biscayne, valued at $US3.96 million.<ref name="RelacionesEmpresario">{{cite news|url=http://noticias.eluniversal.com/2007/08/11/pol_art_relaciones-del-empre_403142.shtml |title=Relaciones del empresario llegan a Mercal |date=11 August 2007 |accessdate=31 July 2008 |work=[[El Universal (Caracas)|El Universal]] |language=es |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080108133612/http://noticias.eluniversal.com/2007/08/11/pol_art_relaciones-del-empre_403142.shtml |archivedate=8 January 2008 |df= }}</ref> Wladimir Abad is the secretary of American Food Grain (AFG),<ref name="MiamiHeraldUnderFire"/> a part of a Venezuelan holding called Proarepa, owned by Sarkis Arslanian Beyloune and Ricardo Fernández Barrueco.<ref name="RelacionesEmpresario"/><ref name="PoliticallyConnected">{{cite news|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2007/12/17/news_pf/State/Politically_connected.shtml|title=Politically connected Venezuelans live high life: Some involved in an international scandal live large in Florida|author=Adams, David|date=17 December 2007|accessdate=30 July 2008|work=St. Petersburg Times}}</ref> Proarepa was in charge of the food distribution during Venezuela's oil strike of 2002, when Chávez signed contracts for food distribution. According to the Venezuelan Government Press Office, Proarepa is a private company that has "joined this mission ([[Mission Mercal]]) to offer food and better price to the Venezuelan consumer".<ref name="RelacionesEmpresario"/> According to ''[[El Nuevo Herald]]'', Antonini Wilson's name is linked to other companies in southern Florida, such as Venuz Supply Inc., Intertel Telecom and Techmilk Inc.;<ref name="RelacionesEmpresario"/><ref name="Intereses">{{cite news|url=http://www.clarin.com/diario/2007/08/11/elpais/p-00701.htm|title=Los intereses económicos de Antonini Wilson en Miami|author=Santoro, Daniel|date=11 August 2007|accessdate=30 July 2008|work=[[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín]]|language=es}}</ref><ref name="AntoniniOpera">{{cite news|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=934708|title=Antonini opera con 'empresas de maletín|date=15 August 2007|accessdate=31 July 2008|work=[[La Nación]]|author=Alconada Mon, Hugo|language=es}}</ref> ''[[La Nación]]'' says that Antonini is among a group of businessmen who benefited economically during the administration of [[Hugo Chávez]].<ref name="AntoniniOpera"/> In May 2007, the U.S. [[Drug Enforcement Administration]] (DEA) confiscated a jet belonging to American Food Grain. The report, according to ''The Miami Herald'', says Ricardo Fernández Barruecos had not respected federal norms to register the plane in the United States.<ref name="RelacionesEmpresario"/><ref name="MiamiHeraldUnderFire">{{cite news |author1=Reyes, Gerardo |author2=San Martin, Nancy | title = Venezuelan is under fire in cash-carrying scandal: An Argentine scandal involving a Key Biscayne Venezuelan has led to a call for dismissal of a Venezuelan government oil official | work = Miami Herald | date = 14 August 2007 | page= A6 | quote = The Key Biscayne man -- Guido Alejandro Antonini Wilson, 46 -- also is an associate of a businessman linked to a large Caracas food conglomerate known to have obtained multimillion-dollar contracts with the government of President Hugo Chávez, El Nuevo Herald has learned. Public records show that Antonini's associate -- both are officers of a Doral company, Techmilk Inc. -- is also an officer of a company that owns an airplane seized by U.S. officials for improper registry -- a circumstance that officials say can sometimes be used to launder money. The Venezuelan-American entrepreneur is the business associate of a Miami pilot whom the Drug Enforcement Administration has cited, in an affidavit, for the alleged illegal use of a U.S. license for an executive plane confiscated in May, El Nuevo Herald has learned. The pilot, Wladimir Abad, is listed as the secretary of American Food Grain, a Venezuelan firm that owns a Raytheon Hawker 800 executive plane seized by the DEA at Fort Lauderdale Airport on 17 May. On Monday, media reports out of Caracas and Buenos Aires said authorities were also seeking the resignation of Diego Uzcátegui Matheus, president of the Argentine subsidiary of the Venezuelan state-owned oil company, PDVSA. His son allegedly invited Antonini on the chartered flight. In Caracas, PDVSA said it had begun an investigation into the ''circumstances and eventual responsibilities'' of the company officials who accompanied Antonini on the flight.}}<!-- formerly at |url = http://www.miamiherald.com/news/americas/story/202380.html |accessdate = 14 August 2007 --> Originally reported at {{cite news | author = Reyes, Gerardo | url = http://www.elnuevoherald.com/167/story/76598.html | title = Venezolano de Miami desata crisis política en Argentina | work = El Nuevo Herald | date = 10 August 2007 | accessdate = 14 August 2007|language=es}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} and {{cite news | author = Reyes, Gerardo | url = http://www.elnuevoherald.com/noticias/america_latina/story/77971.html | title = Empresario del 'valijagate' ligado a piloto bajo lupa de la DEA | work = El Nuevo Herald | page=1A | date = 14 August 2007 | accessdate = 14 August 2007|language=es}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1272/is_2754_136/ai_n24966583/pg_6|title=The corruption of democracy in Venezuela: under Pres. Hugo Chavez's regime the last nine years, corruption has reached heights undreamed of by even the greediest of despots, as the people of Venezuela have been fleeced out of billions of dollars|publisher=Findarticles.com|work=USA Today (Society for the Advancement of Education)|date= March 2008|accessdate=31 July 2008|author=Coronel, Gustavo}}</ref>
Beginning in late August 2007, Antonini Wilson cooperated with the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]], resulting in the "indictment of four Venezuelans and a Uruguayan".<ref name="VenezuelanValise">{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601086&sid=a73rBCz3iDho&refer=latin_america|title=Venezuelan Valise With $790,550 Roils U.S.-Argentina Relations|accessdate=30 July 2008|date=7 January 2008|work=[[Bloomberg.com]]|author=Voreacos, David, Eliana Raszewski and Bill Faries}}</ref> In December 2007, the ''[[St. Petersburg Times]]'' reported that, according to prosecutors, "Antonini was delivering the money to the election campaign of Argentine President [[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner|Cristina Fernandez]]", with "Venezuelan and Argentine officials accusing Washington of fabricating a scandal to destabilize left-wing governments in the region."<ref name="PoliticallyConnected"/> The ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' also reported that: "U.S. prosecutors in Miami announced the arrest of three Venezuelans and a Uruguayan who allegedly schemed to silence Mr. Antonini about the Venezuelan contribution to the Kirchner campaign. An indictment charges the men—and a fifth who is a fugitive—with operating as Venezuelan agents unlawfully, without having notified the U.S. attorney general. In a court hearing, a U.S. attorney said Mr. Antonini is now cooperating with the investigation and wore a wire to record subsequent encounters with the alleged Venezuelan agents, who offered him $2 million in hush money, while also threatening his family if he didn't keep quiet."<ref name="SuitcaseGirl"/>
==Involvement of Cristina Fernández de Kirchner==
On 13 December 2007 the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) arrested three Venezuelans and one Uruguayan, accusing them of being agents of the Venezuelan government who intended for Antonini to help cover up the scandal over the money that was intended for "a candidate" in the [[Argentina presidential election, 2007|Argentine presidential elections of 2007]].<ref name = "ClarinBS">{{cite web | author = Schweimler, Daniel | url = http://www.clarin.com/diario/2007/12/14/um/m-01564344.htm | title = El embajador de Estados Unidos insiste: "Las relaciones con la Argentina son sólidas" | work = Clarin | date = 14 December 2007 | accessdate = 15 December 2007|language=es}}</ref>
The Assistant U.S. Attorney in charge of the case, Thomas Mulvihill, said that one of the arrested individuals, [[Franklin Durán]], had declared that the money was for the then-presidential candidate [[Cristina Fernández de Kirchner]].<ref name="ClarinBS"/><ref name = "Rueters">{{cite news | author = Illiano, Cesar | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSN1351149120071213?feedType=RSS&feedName=worldNews&rpc=22&sp=true | title = Argentina's Fernandez calls U.S. cash probe "garbage" | agency=Reuters | date = 13 December 2007 | accessdate = 15 December 2007 }}</ref>
The Ambassador of the United States to Argentina assured that the event had nothing to do with the [[Argentina-United States relations]].<ref name="Universal">{{cite web|url=http://english.eluniversal.com/2007/12/13/en_pol_art_argentina-rebuts-cri_13A1260683.shtml |title=Argentina rebuts criminal complaint related to the suitcase scandal |work=El Universal |date=13 December 2007 |accessdate=15 December 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080108132753/http://english.eluniversal.com/2007/12/13/en_pol_art_argentina-rebuts-cri_13A1260683.shtml |archivedate=8 January 2008 |df= }}</ref>
Cristina Fernández de Kirchner responded to the investigation led by the United States by dubbing it "''operación basura''" (a "trashing operation").<ref name="Globovision">{{cite web|url=http://www.globovision.com/news.php?nid=73725 |title=Cristina Kirchner dijo que acusaciones de EEUU son "operaciones basura" |work=Globovision |date=13 December 2007 |accessdate=15 December 2007 |language=es |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071215084605/http://www.globovision.com/news.php?nid=73725 |archivedate=15 December 2007 |df= }}</ref>
==Reaction== The Venezuelan ambassador in Buenos Aires declared that Antonini Wilson had nothing to do with the Venezuelan embassy.
[[President of Argentina|Argentine President]] [[Néstor Kirchner]] declared his government had nothing to do with the affair,<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/notas/442384.html | title = Niega Kirchner vínculo con caso dólares | work = [[El Universal (Mexico City)]] | date = 11 August 2007 | accessdate = 14 August 2007|language=es}}</ref> and that there was no coverup.<ref name="MercoPressStashed"/> Venezuela's Minister of Foreign Affairs declared during the third meeting of [[Petrocaribe]], "why is there such a scandal? Every day things like this happen in all the countries of the world". He said the reason for the publicity was that "some powerful people in Washington are very nervous because we are progressing in giant steps towards the union of South American countries, of the Caribbean union. They are afraid and they tremble".
The head of PDVSA, Ramírez, declared "the media is trying to put PDVSA in a bad light for events that are 'completely false'", referring to the recent denouncements of corruption at the state oil company. He said "we see how there is premeditated attempt to publicly lynch our institution and our workers for facts that have not been supported or proved".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.eluniversal.com/2007/08/14/en_pol_art_minister-ramirez-com_14A915307.shtml |title=Minister Ramírez complains about media campaign in suitcase scandal |work=[[El Universal (Caracas)]] |date=14 August 2007 |accessdate=14 August 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080108131128/http://english.eluniversal.com/2007/08/14/en_pol_art_minister-ramirez-com_14A915307.shtml |archivedate=8 January 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.eluniversal.com/2007/08/10/pol_ava_ramirez:-sera-invest_10A913971.shtml |title = Ramírez: Será investigada presencia de funcionarios de Pdvsa en avión con valija | date = 10 August 2007 | work = [[El Universal (Caracas)]] | accessdate = 14 August 2007|language=es}}</ref> The second vice-president of Venezuela's parliament, Roberto Hernández, declared on 10 August that those PDVSA managers who accompanied Antonini Wilson should be fired.
The crisis prompted the Argentine government to ask Chávez to fire the person responsible for PDVSA in Argentina. The PDVSA official's son had accompanied Antonini Wilson to the flight. Other high officials from the Venezuelan and Argentine governments were present.
The Venezuelan Minister of Interior declared that if there were a crime in cooperation with public functionaries, "the State does not have to assume any responsibility because responsibility is individual". He said it is false the Argentine government was asking for the vice-president of PDVSA—Diego Uzcátegui, whose son was traveling with Guido Antonini—to be fired.
On 18 August, President Chávez declared he had nothing to hide.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/08/19/AR2007081901032.html | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20121102204820/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/08/19/AR2007081901032.html | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2 November 2012 | title = Chavez says "nothing to hide" in Argentina scandal | work = [[The Washington Post]]| date = 19 August 2007 | accessdate = 20 August 2007}} Also available from [https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSN1920002120070819 Reuters]. Retrieved 30 July 2008.</ref>
